title: Monitoring Concepts Quiz
description: Test your understanding of application monitoring, logging, and analytics for deployed KMP applications.

questions.text: What is the difference between structured logging and unstructured logging?
options: Structured logging uses XML, unstructured uses JSON
Structured logging emits machine-parseable key-value fields; unstructured outputs free-text strings
Structured logging is for production, unstructured is for development only
There is no difference -- they are the same
questions.explanation: Structured logging outputs log entries as key-value pairs (often JSON) that can be indexed and queried by monitoring tools. Unstructured logging produces human-readable text strings that are harder to search and aggregate programmatically.

questions.text: In a KMP backend (Ktor), what should a health check endpoint return?
options: The full application configuration including secrets
A simple HTTP 200 with basic status info (database connectivity, uptime)
A redirect to the monitoring dashboard
questions.explanation: A health check endpoint returns HTTP 200 with minimal status information (up/down, database reachable, uptime). It should NEVER expose secrets, full configs, or sensitive internal state. Load balancers and orchestrators poll this endpoint to determine instance health.

questions.text: Which metric is MOST important for detecting a memory leak in a Ktor backend?
options: JVM heap usage trending upward over time without returning to baseline
CPU usage spikes during peak hours
questions.explanation: A memory leak shows as JVM heap usage that grows over time and never returns to a stable baseline after garbage collection. Request count and CPU spikes are normal under load. Network bandwidth relates to traffic volume, not memory.
